Repair Strategies for Storage on Mobile Clouds Go khan Cal is we th Shiva rama ah Oz an Ko luo lu and Lou as Laz os Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering The University of Arizona Email cal is shiva rama ah oz an lla zo email arizona edu Abstract We study the data reliability problem for community of devices forming mobile cloud storage system We consider the application of regenerating codes for le maintenance within geographically limited area Such codes require lower bandwidth to regenerate lost data fragments compared to le replication or reconstruction We investigate threshold based repair strategies where data repair is initiated after threshold number of data fragments have been lost due to node mobility We show that at low departure to repair rate regime lazy repair strategy in which repairs are initiated after several nodes have left the system outperforms eager repair in which repairs are initiated after single departure This optimal it is reversed when nodes are highly mobile We further compare distributed and centralized repair strategies and derive the optimal repair threshold for minimizing the average repair cost per unit of time as function of underlying code parameters In addition we examine cooperative repair strategies and show performance improvements compared to non cooperative codes We investigate several models for the time needed for node repair including simplex ed time model that allows for the computation of closed form expressions and more realistic model that takes into account the number of repaired nodes We derive the conditions under which the former model approximates the latter Finally an extended model where additional failures are allowed during the repair process is investigated Overall our results establish the joint effect of code design and repair algorithms on the maintenance cost of distributed storage systems Index Terms Distributed storage regenerating codes mobile cloud data reliability

Mobile Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Vs for Energy Efc ent Internet of Things Communications Mohammad Moz ff ari Walid aad Mehdi Benn is and Mero ne Deb bah Wireless VT Electrical and Computer Engineering Department Virginia Tech VA USA Emails moz ff walid vt edu CWC Centre for Wireless Communications Oulu Finland Email benn is ee oulu Mathematical and Algorithmic Sciences Lab Hua wei France Paris France and Centrale Su pele Universit Paris clay Gif sur Yvette France Email mero ne deb bah hua wei com Abstract In this paper the efc ent deployment and mobility of multiple unmanned aerial vehicles Vs used as aerial base stations to collect data from ground Internet of Things oT devices is investigated In particular to enable reliable uplink communications for oT devices with minimum total transmit power novel framework is proposed for jointly optimizing the three dimensional placement and mobility of the Vs device AV association and uplink power control First given the locations of active oT devices at each time instant the optimal Vs locations and associations are determined Next to dynamically serve the oT devices in time varying network the optimal mobility patterns of the Vs are analyzed To this end based on the activation process of the oT devices the time instances at which the Vs must update their locations are derived Moreover the optimal trajectory of each AV is obtained in way that the total energy used for the mobility of the Vs is minimized while serving the oT devices Simulation results show that using the proposed approach the total transmit power of the oT devices is reduced by compared to case in which stationary aerial base stations are deployed In addition the proposed approach can yield maximum of enhanced system reliability compared to the stationary case The results also reveal an inherent tradeoff between the number of update times the mobility of the Vs and the transmit power of the oT devices In essence higher number of updates can lead to lower transmit powers for the oT devices at the cost of an increased mobility for the Vs

Computation Peer Of ding for Energy Constrained Mobile Edge Computing in Small Cell Networks Li xing Chen Student Member IEEE Sheng Zhou Member IEEE Jie Xu Member IEEE Abstract The ultra dense deployment of small cell base stations SBS endowed with cloud like computing functionalities paves the way for pervasive mobile edge computing ME enabling ultra low latency and location awareness for variety of emerging mobile applications and the Internet of Things To handle spatially uneven computation workloads in the network cooperation among SBS via workload peer of ding is essential to avoid large computation latency at overloaded SBS and provide high quality of service to end users However performing effective peer of ding faces many unique challenges due to limited energy resources committed by self interested SBS owners uncertainties in the system dynamics and co provisioning of radio access and computing services This paper develops novel online SBS peer of ding framework called OPEN by leveraging the Lyapunov technique in order to maximize the long term system performance while keeping the energy consumption of SBS below individual long term constraints OPEN works online without requiring information about future system dynamics yet provides provably near optimal performance compared to the oracle solution that has the complete future information In addition this paper formulates peer of ding game among SBS analyzes its equilibrium and efc ien cy loss in terms of the price of anarchy to thoroughly understand SBS strategic behaviors there by enabling decentralized and autonomous peer of ding decision making Extensive simulations are carried out and show that peer of ding among SBS dramatically improves the edge computing performance Chen and Xu are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering University of Miami USA Email chen miami edu jie xu miami edu Zhou is with the Department of Electronic Engineering Tsinghua University China Email sheng zhou tsinghua edu cn

Information spreading during emergencies and anomalous events James Ba grow Abstract The most critical time for information to spread is in the aftermath of serious emergency crisis or disaster Individuals affected by such situations can now turn to an array of communication channels from mobile phone calls and text messages to social media posts when alerting social ties These channels dr asti call improve the speed of information in time sensitive event and provide extant records of human dynamics during and afterward the event Retrospective analysis of such anomalous events provides researchers with class of found experiments that may be used to better understand social spreading In this chapter we study information spreading due to number of emergency events including the Boston Marathon Bombing and plane crash at western European airport We also con tra st the different information which maybe gleaned by social media data compared with mobile phone data and we estimate the rate of anomalous events in mobile phone data set using proposed anomaly detection method

Online Geographical Load Balancing for Mobile Edge Computing with Energy Harvesting Jie Xu Hang Wu Li xing Chen Cong Shen Abstract Mobile Edge Computing ME fog computing has recently emerged to enable low latency and location aware data processing at the edge of mobile networks Since providing grid power supply in support of ME can be costly and even infeasible in some scenarios on site renewable energy is mandated as major or even sole power supply Nonetheless the high inter mitten cy and unpredictability of energy harvesting creates many new challenges of performing effective ME In this paper we develop an algorithm called GLOBE that performs joint geographical load balancing LB and admission control for optimizing the system performance of network of ME enabled and energy harvesting powered base stations By leveraging and extending the Lyapunov optimization with perturbation tech ni que GLOBE operates online without requiring future system information and addresses sign cant challenges caused by battery state dynamics and energy causality constraints Moreover GLOBE works in distributed manner which makes our algorithm scalable to large networks We prove that GLOBE achieves close to optimal system performance compared to the of in algorithm that knows full future information and present critical tradeoff between battery capacity and system performance Simulation results validate our analysis and demonstrate the superior performance of GLOBE compared to benchmark algorithms

multiple mobile users is essential for many applications such as search and res cue in disaster areas or human social interaction Inertial measurement unit IMU is promising to determine the change of International Journal of Computer Networks Communications JC NC Vol No March AT GREG ATION OUTING RO TO COLS IN IRE LESS ENS OR ET WORKS TAXONOMY eid Pour roost aei Arda kani All meh Tabata bai University Tehran Iran ABSTRACT Routing in Wireless Sensor Network WS aims to interconnect sensor nodes via single or multi hop paths The routes are established to forward data packets from sensor nodes to the sink Establishing single path to report each data packet results in increasing energy consumption in WS hence data aggregation routing is used to combine data packets and consequently reduce the number of transmissions This reduces the routing overhead by eliminating redundant and meaningless data There are two models for data aggregation routing in WS mobile agent and client server This paper describes data aggregation routing and classifies then the routing protocols according to the network architecture and routing models The key issues of the data aggregation routing models client server and mobile agent are highlighted and discussed KEYWORDS Wireless Sensor Networks Routing Protocols Data Aggregation Client server Mobile Agent

Joint Spectrum Reservation and On demand Request for Mobile Virtual Network Operators Ying xiao Zhang Su zhi Bi and Ying Jun Angela Zhang Abstract Wireless network virtualization enables mobile virtual network operators MV NOs to develop new services on low cost platform by leasing virtual resources from mobile network owners In this paper we investigate two stage spectrum leasing framework where an MV NO acquires radio spectrum through both advance reservation and on demand request To maximize its surplus the MV NO jointly optimizes the amount of spectrum to lease in each stage by taking into account the tr afc distribution random user locations wireless channel statistics quality of service requirements and the prices differences Meanwhile the MV NO dynamically allocates the acquired spectrum resources to its mobile subscribers users according to fast channel fading in order to maximize the utilization of the resources The MV NOs surplus maximization problem is formulated as tri level nested optimization problem consisting of dynamic resource allocation DRA on demand request and advance reservation sub problems To solve the problem efc ent ly we rst analyze the DRA problem and then use the optimal solution to nd the optimal leasing decisions in the two stages In particular we derive closed form expression of the optimal on demand request and develop stochastic gradient descent algorithm to nd the optimal advance reservation For special case when the proportional fairness utility is adopted we show that the optimal two stage leasing scheme is related to the number of users and is irrelevant to user locations Simulation results show that the two stage spectrum leasing scheme can adapt to different levels of tr afc and on demand price variations and achieve higher surplus than conventional one stage leasing schemes Index Terms radio spectrum management mobile virtual network operator stochastic optimization This work has been presented in part in IEEE ICC Shenzhen China Ying xiao Zhang and Ying Jun Angela Zhang are with the Department of Information Engineering The Chinese University of Hong Kong HK Email zy yj zhang ie cu hk edu hk Su zhi Bi uci ent Markov Decision Processes with Alternating Deep Neural Networks Long shao kan Wang Eric La ber Katie Wit kiew itz Department of Statistics North Carolina State University Raleigh NC Department of Psychology University of New Mexico Albuquerque NM Abstract Advances in mobile computing technologies have made it possible to monitor and apply data driven interventions across complex systems in real time Recent and high role examples of data driven decision making include autonomous vehicles intelligent power grids and precision medicine through mobile health Markov decision processes are the primary mathematical model for sequential decision problems with large or in de nite time horizon existing methods for estimation and inference rely critically on the correctness of this model Mathematically this choice of model incurs little loss in generality as any decision process evolving in discrete time with observable process states decisions and outcomes can be represented as Markov decision process However in some application domains mobile health choosing representation of the underlying decision process that is both Markov and low dimensional is non trivial current practice is to select representation using domain expertise We propose an automated method for constructing low dimensional representation of the original decision process for which the Markov decision process model holds and decision strategy that leads to maximal mean utility when applied to the low dimensional representation also leads to maximal mean utility when applied to population of interest Our approach uses novel deep neural network to de ne class of potential process representations and then searches within this class for the representation of lowest dimension which satis es and We illustrate the proposed method using suite of simulation experiments and application to data from mobile health intervention targeting smoking and heavy episodic drinking among college students

Uplink performance of multi antenna cellular networks with co operative base stations and user centric clustering Siddh art an Govinda samy It sik Berg el Abstract We consider user centric co operative cellular network where base stations BS close to mobile co operate to detect its signal using joint linear minimum mean square error receiver The BS are at arbitrary positions and mobiles are modeled as planar Poisson Point Process PPP Combining stochastic geometry and in nite random matrix theory we derive simple expression for the spectral efc ien cy of this complex system as the number of antennas grows large This framework is applied to BS locations from PPP and hexagonal grids and are validated through Monte Carlo simulations The results reveal the in en ce of tangible system parameters such as mobile and base station densities number of antennas per BS and number of co operating BS on achievable spectral efc ien cie Among other insights we nd that for given BS density and constraint on the total number of co operating antennas all co operating antennas should be located at single BS On the other hand in our asymptotic regime for the same number of co operating antennas if the network is limited by the area density of antennas then the number of co operating BS should be increased with fewer antennas per BS Index Terms Cellular Networks IMO Antenna Arrays Stochastic Geometry Poisson Point Process

Joint Task Of ding and Resource Allocation for Multi Server Mobile Edge Computing Networks Tu yen Tr an Student Member IEEE and Dario Pomp ili Senior Member IEEE Abstract Mobile Edge Computing ME is an emerging paradigm that provides capillary distribution of cloud computing capabilities to the edge of the wireless access network enabling rich services and applications in close proximity to the end users In this article ME enabled multi cell wireless network is considered where each Base Station BS is equipped withaM EC server that can assist mobile users in executing computation intensive tasks via task of ding The problem of Joint Task Of ding and Resource Allocation TORA is studied in order to maximize the users task of ding gains which is measured by the reduction in task completion time and energy consumption The considered problem is formulated as Mixed Integer Non linear Program MIN LP that involves jointly optimizing the task of ding decision uplink transmission power of mobile users and computing resource allocation at the ME servers Due to the NP hardness of this problem solving for optimal solution is if cult and impractical for large scale network To overcome this drawback our approach is to decompose the original problem into Resource Allocation RA problem with ed task of ding decision and ii Task Of ding TO problem that optimizes the optimal value function corresponding to the RA problem We address the RA problem using convex and quasi convex optimization techniques and propose novel heuristic algorithm to the TO problem that achieves suboptimal solution in polynomial time Numerical simulation results show that our algorithm performs closely to the optimal solution and that it sign cant ly improves the users of ding utility over traditional approaches Index Terms Mobile edge computing computation of ding multi server resource allocation distributed ys tem The authors are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering Rutgers University New Brunswick NJ USA mail tu yen tr an rutgers edu pomp ili cac rutgers edu This work was supported by the National Science Foundation NSF Grant No CNS

sensors Article An Authentication Protocol for Future Sensor Networks Muhammad Bilal and Shin Gak Kang Electronics and Telecommunications Research Institute University of Science and Technology Ga jeong ro yu seong gu Daejeon Korea sg kang tri re kr Correspondence bilal tri re kr Tel DOI Abstract Authentication is one of the essential security services in Wireless Sensor Networks SNs for ensuring secure data sessions Sensor node authentication ensures the conde nti ali ty and validity of data collected by the sensor node whereas user authentication guarantees that only legitimate users can access the sensor data In mobile WS sensor and user nodes move across the network and exchange data with multiple nodes thus experiencing the authentication process multiple times The integration of SNs with Internet of Things oT brings forth new kind of WS architecture along with stricter security requirements for instance sensor node or user node may need to establish multiple concurrent secure data sessions With concurrent data sessions the frequency of there authentication process increases in proportion to the number of concurrent connections Moreover to establish multiple data sessions it is essential that protocol participant have the capability of running multiple instances of the protocol run which makes the security issue even more challenging The currently available authentication protocols were designed for the autonomous WS and do not account for the above requirements Hence ensuring lightweight and efc ent authentication protocol has become more crucial In this paper we present novel lightweight and efc ent key exchange and authentication protocol suite called the Secure Mobile Sensor Network MSN Authentication Protocol In the MSN mobile node goes through an initial authentication procedure and receives re authentication ticket from the base station Later mobile node can use this re authentication ticket when establishing multiple data exchange sessions and or when moving across the network This scheme reduces the communication and computational complexity of the authentication process We proved the strength of our protocol with rigorous security analysis including formal analysis using the BAN logic and simulated the MSN and previously proposed schemes in an automated protocol verier tool Finally we compared the computational complexity and communication cost against well known authentication protocols Keywords authentication sensor networks network security key distribution privacy BAN logic

Be nets of Mobile End User Network Switching and Multi homing Finley Bas aure Department of Communications and Networking Aalto University one mie hen tie Espoo Finland bF cult ad de In genie ra Ciencia pli cad as Universidad de los Andes Av Monse or lvaro del Portillo Santiago Chile Abstract Mobile users have not been able to exploit patio temporal dieren ces between individual mobile networks operators for variety of reasons End user network switching and multi homing are two promising mecha isms that could allow such exploitation However these mechanisms have not been thoroughly explored at general system level with Qo metrics Therefore in this work we analyze these mechanisms in variety of diverse scenarios through system level model based on an agent based modeling framework In terms of results wend that in all scenarios end user network switching provides sign cant be nets in terms of both throughput and mean opinion score as the number of available networks increases However contrast ingly end user multi homing in most scenarios does not provide sign cant be nets over network switching given the same number of available networks The major reason is in ec ent radio resource allocation resulting from individual networks not taking the multi homing nature of end users into account Though in low user density situations this in ec ien cy is not problem and multi homing does provide increased throughput though not increased mean opinion scores Finally scenarios that vary the fraction of users adopting multi homing suggests that both early and late adopters will have similar gains over users not adopting multi homing Thus the adoption dynamics of multi homing appear favorable Overall the results support the applicability of end user network switching for improving mobile user experience and the applicability of end user multi homing in more limited situations Keywords Network Switching Multi homing Qo Al locative Ec ien cy User Driven Competition Agent Based Modeling

Time Accuracy Analysis of Post Mediation Packet Switched Charging Data Records for Urban Mobility Applications Oscar Per edo Romain Deschamps Telefonica Chile Telefonica Chile Abstract Telecommunication data is being used increasingly in urban mobility applications around the world Despite its ubiquity and usefulness technical if cul ties arise when using Packet Switched Charging Data Records CDR since its main purpose was not intended for this kind of applications Due to its particular nature trade off must be considered between accessibility and time accuracy when using this data On the one hand to obtain highly accurate time stamps huge amounts of network level CDR must be extracted and stored This task is very if cult and expensive since highly critical network node applications can be compromised in the data extraction and storage On the other hand post mediation CDR can be easily accessed since no network node application is involved in its analysis The pay off is in the lower accurate time stamps recorded since several aggregations and lte ring is performed in previous steps of the charging pipelines In this work detailed description of the timestamp error problem using post mediation CDR is presented together with methodology to analyze error time series collected in each network cell Fig Core networks implied diagram

Analysing Human Mobility Patterns of Hiking Activities through Complex Network Theory Isaac Ler Toni Perez Carlos Guerrero ctor gu luz Carlos Ju iz Depart men to de Mate mati cas In format ica Universitat de les Ille Balear Palma de Mallorca Spain Instituto de sica Inter disc ipl in ar Sistema Comp le jos IF IS SIC IB Palma de Mallorca Spain mail isaac ler ib es IL Abstract The exploitation of high volume of geo localized data from social sport tracking applications of outdoor activities can be useful for natural resource planning and to understand the human mobility patterns during leisure activities This geo localized data represents the selection of hike activities according to subjective and objective factors such as personal goals personal abilities trail conditions or weather conditions In our approach human mobility patterns are analysed from trajectories which are generated by hikers We propose the generation of the trail network identifying special points in the overlap of trajectories Trail crossings and trail heads define our network and shape topological features We analyse the trail network of Balearic Islands as case of study using complex weighted network theory The analysis is divided into the four seasons of the year to observe the impact of weather conditions on the network topology The number of visited places does not decrease despite the large difference in the number of samples of the two seasons with larger and lower activity It is in summer season where it is produced the most significant variation in the frequency and localization of activities from inland regions to coastal areas Finally we compare our model with other related studies where the network possesses different purpose One finding of our approach is the detection of regions with relevant importance where landscape interventions can be applied in function of the communities

Energy Sustainable Tr afc Steering for Mobile Networks Shan Zhang Member IEEE Ning Zhang Member IEEE Sheng Zhou Member IEEE Jie Gong Member IEEE Zhi sheng Niu Fellow IEEE and Xue min Sherman Shen Fellow IEEE Abstract Renewable energy harvesting EH technology is expected to be pervasive ly utilized in the next generation mobile networks to support sustainable network developments and operations However the renewable energy supply is inherently random and intermittent which could lead to energy outage energy over ow quality of service Qo degradation etc Accordingly how to enhance renewable energy sustainability is critical issue for green networking To this end an energy sustainable tr afc steering framework is proposed in this article where the tr afc load is dynamically adjusted to match with energy distributions in both spatial and temporal domains by means of inter and intra tier steering caching and pushing Case studies are carried out which demonstrate the proposed framework can reduce on grid energy demand while satisfying Qo requirements Research topics and challenges of energy sustainable tr afc steering are also discussed Shan Zhang and Xue min Sherman Shen are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering University of Waterloo University Avenue West Waterloo Ontario Canada Email zh an waterloo ca shen bbc waterloo ca Ning Zhang is with the Department of Computing Science Texas University Corpus Christi Ocean Dr Corpus Christi Texas USA Email zhang ning up gmail com Sheng Zhou and Zhi sheng Niu are with Tsinghua National Laboratory for Information Science and Technology Tsinghua University Beijing China Email sheng zhou niu zh tsinghua edu cn Jie Gong is with the School of Data and Computer Science SunY at Sen University Guangzhou China Email xiao cie gmail com This work is sponsored in part by the National Nature Science Foundation of China No No No Hitachi Headquarter and Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada

Fast Cell Discovery in mm wave Networks with Context Information lario Filip pin Senior Member IEEE Vincenzo Sci an cale pore Member IEEE Francesco Devo ti and Antonio Capone Senior Member IEEE Abstract The exploitation of mm wave bands is one of the key enable for mobile radio networks However the introduction of mm wave technologies in cellular networks is not straightforward due to harsh propagation conditions that limit the mm wave access availability Mm wave technologies require high gain antenna systems to compensate for high path loss and limited power As consequence directional transmissions must be used for cell discovery and synchronization processes this can lead to non negligible access delay caused by the exploration of the cell area with multiple transmissions along different directions The integration of mm wave technologies and conventional wireless access networks with the objective of speeding up the cell search process requires new network architectural solutions Such architectures introduce functional split between plane and plane there by guaranteeing the availability of reliable signaling channel through conventional wireless technologies that provides the opportunity to collect useful context information from the network edge In this article we leverage the context information related to user positions to improve the directional cell discovery process We investigate fundamental trade offs of this process and the effects of the context information accuracy on the overall system performance We also cope with obstacle obstructions in the cell area and propose an approach based on geo located context database where information gathered overtime is stored to guide future searches Analytic models and numerical results are provided to validate proposed strategies Index Terms networks mm wave radio access RAN directional cell discovery context information obstacle shadowing ree ted paths

HUMAN MOBILITY MINING THROUGH HEAD TAIL BREAKS Karim Ke ramat Jah rom Department of computer science University of Milan Via Come li co Milan Italy Karim Ke ramat uni mi it Abstract Nowadays as the world population has become more interconnected and is relying on faster transportation methods simplified connections and shorter commuting times we witness rapid increase in human mobility In this situation unveiling and understanding human mobility patterns have become crucial issue to support decisions and prediction activities when managing the complexity of the todays social organization In practice the mobility pattern of each individual person consists of the sequence of visited places Points of interest Those places and their correlations represent the foundation of most modelling and activity researches for understanding human mobility Even though visited places underpin almost the majority of works in this field their features remain largely unknown because in previous works they have been mainly considered as un characterized spot points in an area or social gathering places without considering the roles and importance of places to the behavior of each single user In this paper framework to deal with the importance of places from perspective of an individual mobile user is proposed Considering that most of the features and properties of human mobility show heavy tail trend because of the hierarchy structure and high level of he te rogen ei ties in peoples movement therefore we are motivated to use Head Tail breaks for mining and classification of mobility features instead of applying the classical approaches such as Means etc since we expect that the Head Tail breaks can better capture and retrieve the heterogeneity in peoples movement On the other hand in recent years the large availability of smartphones combined with the pervasive availability of communication infrastructures gave rise of collecting the datasets recording human mobility providing basis to validate our work on larger scale Pilot datasets that used for analysis are Cellular and Wi fi datasets collected from smartphones Keywords Human Mobility Analysis Head Tail breaks Points of Interest Cellular Network Data Wi Fi data set

Drone Cells Improving Spectral Efc ien cy using Drone mounted Flying Base Stations Azad Foto hi Ming Ding and Mah bu Hassan Abstract We study acellular networking scenario called Drone Cells where miniaturized base stations BS are mounted on ying drones to serve mobile users We propose that the drones never stop and move continuously within the cell in away that reduces the distance between the BS and the serving users thus potentially improving the spectral efc ien cy of the network By considering the practical mobility constraints of commercial drones we design drone mobility algorithms to improve the spectral efc ien cy of Drone Cells As the optimal problem is NP hard we propose range of practically realizable heuristics with varying complexity and performance Simulations show that using the existing consumer drones the proposed algorithms can readily improve spectral efc ien cy by and the percentile packet throughput by compared to the scenario where drones hover over ed locations More sign cant gains can be expected with more agile drones in the future surprising outcome is that the drones need toy only at minimal speeds to achieve these gains avoiding any negative effect on drone battery lifetime We further demonstrate that the optimal solution provides only modest improvements over the best heuristic algorithm which employs Game Theory to make mobility decisions for drone BS Index Terms Drone Base Station Spectral Efc ien cy Performance Evaluation Mobility Control Game Theory cid

Localization in random bipartite graphs numerical and empirical study Franti sek Slan in Institute of Physics Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic Na Slovan ce CZ Praha Czech Republic Dated July We investigate adj ace cy matrices of bipartite graphs with power law degree distribution Mo iv ation for this study is twofold First vibrational states in granular matter and jammed sphere packing second graphs encoding social interaction especially electronic commerce We establish the position of the mobility edge and show that it strongly depends on the power in the degree distribution and on the ratio of the sizes of the two parts of the bipartite graph At the jamming threshold where the two parts have the same size localization vanishes We found that the mul ti fractal spectrum is non trivial in the delocalized phase but still near the mobility edge We also study an empirical bipartite graph namely the Amazon reviewer item network We found that in this spec ic graph mobility edge disappears and we draw conclusion from this fact regarding earlier empirical studies of the Amazon network PAC numbers Lm

International Journal of Ad hoc Sensor Ubiquitous Computing IJ AS UC Vol No June AN OPPORTUNISTIC AO DV ROUTING SCHEME OGNI TI VE BILE GENTS PP ROACH Seem He de and this Babu Department of Computer Science and Engineering Sid da ganga Institute of Technology Tum kur Karnataka India Palla pa Ven kat arm PET Unit Electrical Communication Engineering Indian Institute of Science Bangalore Karnataka India ABSTRACT In Manet Dynamics and Robustness are the key features of the nodes and are governed by several routing protocols such as AO DV SR and so on However in the network the growing resource demand leads to resource scarcity The Node Mobility often leads to the link breakages and high routing overhead decreasing the stability and reliability of the network connectivity In this context the paper proposes novel opportunistic AO DV routing scheme which implements cognitive agent based intelligent technique to set up stable connectivity over the Manet The Scheme computes the routing metric rf based on the collaboration sensitivity levels of the nodes obtained based through the knowledge based decision This Routing Metric is subsequently used to set up the stable path for network connectivity Thus minimizes the route overhead and increases the stability of the path The Performance evaluation is conducted in comparison with the AO DV and sleep AO DV routing protocol and validated KEYWORDS Mobile Ad hoc Networks AO DV Opportunistic network Cognitive agents Routing factor Sleep AO DV

Deep Fisher Discriminant Learning for Mobile Hand Gesture Recognition Chun yu Xie Ce Lib Bao chang Zhang Chen Chen Jun gong Hand Department of Automation Bei hang University Beijing China Department of Computer Science China University of Mining and Technology Beijing China University of Central Florida Orlando FL USA Nor umbria Un ives it Newcastle UK Abstract Gesture recognition is challenging problem in the el of biometrics In this paper we integrate Fisher criterion into Bidirectional Long Short Term Memory BL STM network and Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit GRU thus leading to two new deep models termed as BL STM and GRU Both Fisher disc rim native deep models can eec iv ely classify the gesture based on analyzing the acceleration and angular velocity data of the human gestures Moreover we collect large Mobile Gesture Database MG based on the accelerations and angular velocities containing sequences of gestures Extensive experiments are conducted to validate the superior performance of the proposed networks as compared to the state of the art BL STM and GRU on MG database and two benchmark databases BU mobile gesture and Smart Watch gesture Keywords Fisher Discriminant Hand Gesture Recognition Mobile Devices

Non equilibrium phase diagram of quasi periodic system with single particle mobility edge Arch ak Pur kayastha Abhi shek har and Man as Kul karn International centre for theoretical sciences Tata Institute of Fundamental Research Bangalore India Dated December We investigate and map out the non equilibrium phase diagram of generalization of the well known Aubry Andre Harper AH model This generalized AH GAA model is known to have single particle mobility edge which also has an additional self dual property akin to that of the critical point of AH model By calculating the population imbalance we get hints of rich phase diagram We also nd fascinating connection between single particle wavefunctions near the mobility edge of GAA model and the wavefunctions of the critical AH model By placing this model far from equilibrium with the aid of two baths we investigate the open system transport via system size scaling of non equilibrium steady state NESS current calculated by fully exact non equilibrium Greens function NE GF formalism The critical point of the AH model now generalizes to critical line separating regions of ballistic and localized transport Like the critical point of AH model current scales sub diu siv ely with system size on the critical line However remarkably the scaling exponent on this line is distinctly die rent from that obtained for the critical AH model where All these results can be understood from the above mentioned connection between states near mobility edge of GAA model and those of critical AH model very interesting high temperature non equilibrium phase diagram of the GAA model emerges from our calculations

Cost Effective Cache Deployment in Mobile Heterogeneous Networks Shan Zhang Member IEEE Ning Zhang Member IEEE Peng Yang Student Member IEEE and Xue min Sherman Shen Fellow IEEE Abstract This paper investigates one of the fundamental issues in cache enabled heterogeneous networks He Nets how many cache instances should be deployed at different base stations in order to provide guaranteed service in cost effective manner Spec ic ally we consider two tier He Nets with hierarchical caching where the most popular les are cached at small cell base stations SBS while the less popular ones are cached at macro base stations MBS For given network cache deployment budget the cache sizes for MBS and SBS are optimized to maximize network capacity while satisfying the le transmission rate requirements As cache sizes of MBS and SBS affect the tr afc load distribution inter tier tr afc steering is also employed for load balancing Based on stochastic geometry analysis the optimal cache sizes for MBS and SBS are obtained which are threshold based with respect to cache budget in the networks constrained by SBS back hauls Simulation results are provided to evaluate the proposed schemes and demonstrate the applications in cost effective network deployment Index Terms mobile edge caching heterogeneous networks constrained back haul stochastic geometry

Urban FACET Visually Pro ling Cities from Mobile Device Recorded Movement Data of Millions of City Residents Le iShi Tao Jiang Ye Zhao Xia tian Zhang and Yao Lu Fig The visualization interface of Urban FACET the selection on city and time the selection of mobility metrics displayed on the map and the visualization options detailed information on the selected region the whole city by default if nothing is selected probability density function of the displayed mobility metric average probability distribution on POI DIV classes to compute the mobility metric the spatial visualization of mobility metrics vibrancy in this case legend and controller of the map Abstract Cities are living systems where urban infrastructures and their functions are de ned and evolved due to population behaviors Pro ling the cities and functional regions has been an important topic in urban design and planning This paper studies unique big data set which includes daily movement data often of millions of city residents and develop visual analytics system namely Urban FACET to discover and visualize the dynamical roles of multiple cities and their residents This big user movement data set acquired from mobile users agnostic check in at thousands of phone APPs is well utilized in an integrative study and visualization together with urban structure road network and POI Point of Interest distributions In particular we novel ly develop set of information theory based metrics to characterize the mobility patterns of city areas and groups of residents These multifaceted metrics including Fluidity vibrAncy Commutation divErsity and densiTy FACET which categorize and manifest hidden urban functions and behaviors Urban FACET system further allows users to visually analyze and compare the metrics over different areas and cities in metropolitan scales The system is evaluated through both case studies on several big and heavily populated cities and user studies involving real world users

Extracting and Exploiting Inherent Sparsity for Efc ent oT Support in Challenges and Potential Solutions Basse Khal Student Member IEEE Be chi Ham da oui Senior Member IEEE and Mohsen Gui zan Fellow Member IEEE Abstract Besides enabling an enhanced mobile broadband next generation of mobile networks are envisioned for the support of massive connectivity of heterogeneous Internet of Things oT These oTs are envisioned for large number of use cases including smart cities environment monitoring smart vehicles etc Unfortunately most oTs have very limited computing and storage capabilities and need cloud services Hence connecting these devices through systems requires huge spectrum resources in addition to handling the massive connectivity and improved security This article discusses the challenges facing the support of oTs through systems The focus is devoted to discussing physical layer limitations in terms of spectrum resources and radio access channel connectivity We show how sparsity can be exploited for addressing these challenges especially in terms of enabling wide band spectrum management and handling the connectivity by exploiting device to device communications and edge cloud Moreover we identify major open problems and research directions that need to be explored towards enabling the support of massive heterogeneous oTs through systems

Projection Net Learning Efc ent On Device Deep Networks Using Neural Projections uji th Ravi Google Research Mountain View CA USA ravi google com Abstract Deep neural networks have become ubiquitous for applications related to visual recognition and language understanding tasks However it is often prohibitive to use typical neural network models on devices like mobile phones or smart watches since the model sizes are huge and cannot tin the limited memory available on such devices While these devices could make use of machine learning models running on high performance datacenter with CPUs or GPUs this is not feasible for many applications because data can be privacy sensitive and inference needs to be performed directly on device We introduce new architecture for training compact neural networks using joint optimization framework At it score lies novel objective that jointly trains using two different types of networks full trainer neural network using existing architectures like Feed forward NN or STM RN Ns combined with simpler projection network that leverages random projections to transform inputs or in ter mediate representations into bits The simpler network encodes lightweight and efc ent to compute operations in bit space with low memory footprint The two networks are trained jointly using back propagation where the projection network learns from the full network similar to apprenticeship learning Once trained the smaller network can be used directly for inference at low memory and computation cost We demonstrate the effectiveness of the new approach at sign if cant ly shrinking the memory requirements of different types of neural networks while preserving good accuracy for several visual recognition and text classic tion tasks We also study the question how many neural bits are required to solve given task using the new framework and show empirical results contrasting model predictive capacity in bits versus accuracy on several datasets Finally we show how the approach can be extended to other learning settings and derive projection models optimized using graph structured loss functions

Concealing IMS in Network Using Identity Based Encryption Mohsin Khan and Val tter Niemi cid University of Helsinki Helsinki Finland mohsin khan helsinki fi val tter niemi helsinki fi Abstract Subscription privacy of user has been historical concern with all the previous generation mobile networks namely GSM MTS and LTE While little improvement have been achieved in securing the privacy of the long term identity of subscriber the so called IMS catchers are still in existence even in the LTE and advanced LTE net works Proposals have been published to tackle this problem in based on pseudonyms and die rent public key technologies This paper looks into the problem of concealing long term identity of subscriber and presents technique based on identity based encryption BE to tackle it The proposed solution can be extended to mutual authentication and key agreement protocol between serving network SN and user equipment UE This mutual authentication and key agreement pro to col does not need to connect with the home network HN on every run qualitative comparison of the advantages and disadvantages of die rent techniques show that our solution is competitive for securing the long term identity privacy of user in the network

Emotion Controlled Spectrum Mobility Scheme for Efficient Syntactic Interoperability In Cognitive Radio Based Internet of Vehicles Faisal Riaz Mu az Niazi Dept Of Computing and Technology Iqr University Islamabad Pakistan Dept Of Computer Sciences COMS AT Islamabad Pakistan Email fa zi ku yahoo com mu az niazi gmail com Abstract Blind spots are one of the causes of road accidents in the hilly and flat areas These blind spot accidents can be decreased by establishing an Internet of Vehicles oV using Vehicle Vehicle and Vehicle Infra str tru ture communication systems But the problem with these oV is that most of them are using DS RC or single Radio Access Technology RAT as wireless technology which has been proven to be failed for efficient communication between vehicles Recently Cognitive Radio CR based oV have to be proven best wireless communication systems for vehicular networks However the spectrum mobility is challenging task to keep CR based vehicular networks interoperable and has not been addressed sufficiently in existing research In our previous research work the Cognitive Radio Site CR Site has been proposed as in vehicle CR device which can be utilized to establish efficient oV systems However the CR Site is not capable to solve the spectrum mobility challenge in high speed oV systems In this paper we have introduced the Emotions Inspired Cognitive Agent EI Agent based spectrum mobility mechanism in CR Site and proposed novel emotions controlled spectrum mobility scheme for efficient syntactic interoperability between vehicles For this purpose probabilistic deterministic finite automaton using fear factor is proposed to perform efficient spectrum mobility using fuzzy logic In addition the quantitative computation of different fear intensity levels has been performed with the help of fuzzy logic The system has been tested using active data from different GSM service providers on Mangla Mirpur road This is supplemented by extensive simulation experiments which validate the proposed scheme for CR based high speed vehicular networks The qualitative comparison with the existing state of the art has proven the superiority of the proposed emotions controlled syntactic interoperable spectrum mobility scheme within cognitive radio based oV systems Keywords Affective Computing Cognitive Radio Fear Fuzzy Logic Syntactic Interoperability Vehicular Networks

Ultra Reliable Low Latency Cellular Networks Use Cases Challenges and Approaches He Chen Rana Abbas Peng Cheng Mah yar Shirvani mogh add am Wi bow Hard jaw an Wei Bao Yong hui Li and rank Vu ceti The University of Sydney NSW Australia Email first name lastname sydney edu au Abstract The fifth generation cellular mobile networks are expected to support mission critical ultra reliable low latency communication URL LC services in addition to the enhanced mobile broadband applications This article first introduces three emerging mission critical applications of URL LC and identifies their requirements on end to end latency and reliability We then investigate the various sources of end to end delay of current wireless networks by taking the Long Term Evolution LTE as an example Subsequently we propose and evaluate several techniques to reduce the end to end latency from the perspectives of error control coding signal processing and radio resource management We also briefly discuss other network design approaches with the potential for further latency reduction

Wireless Networks for Mobile Edge Computing Spatial Modeling and Latency Analysis Seung Woo Ko Kai feng Han and Kai bin Huang Abstract Next generation wireless networks will provide users ubiquitous low latency computing services using devices at the network edge called mobile edge computing ME The key operation of ME is to of ad computation intensive tasks from users Since each edge device comprises an access point AP and computer server CS ME network can be decomposed as radio access network cascaded with CS network Based on the architecture we investigate network constrained latency performance namely communication latency and computation latency under the constraints of radio access coverage and CS stability To this end spatial random network is modelled featuring random node distribution parallel computing non orthogonal multiple access and random computation task generation Given the model and the said network constraints we derive the scaling laws of communication latency and computation latency with respect to network load parameters density of mobiles and their task generation rates and network resource parameters bandwidth density of APs CSs CS computation rate Essentially the analysis involves the interplay of theories of stochastic geometry queueing and parallel computing Combining the derived scaling laws quan ties the tradeoffs between the latencies network coverage and network stability The results provide useful guidelines for ME network pro vi sion ing and planning by avoiding either of the cascaded radio access network or CS network being performance bottleneck
